article.title: Low-frequency phase diagram of irradiated graphene and periodically driven spin-1/2 $XY$ chain

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the red and black solid lines in Figure 2 represent?
choices: The phase bands of the system
The probability of excitations
The instantaneous ground and excited state energies
The wave function overlap

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the green dashed line in Figure 2 represent?
choices: The overlap of ground states in adiabatic and diabatic bases.
The Stueckelberg phase
The Landau-Zener probability
The kinematic phase

multiple_choice_question.text: How does the number of avoided crossings vary with different k points in the Brillouin zone?
choices: It remains constant.
It is always even.
It is always odd.
It varies depending on the k point.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the symmetry of the instantaneous eigenvalues in Figure 2 imply?
choices: The presence of time-reversal symmetry
Periodic repetition of energy levels within a drive cycle
The absence of Landau-Zener transitions
Equal probabilities for all avoided level crossings

multiple_choice_question.text: What is being compared in Figure 3?
choices: Exact numerical results and results from high-frequency expansion techniques
Phase bands calculated using the adiabatic-impulse approximation and exact numerics
Landau-Zener probabilities and Stuckelberg phases
Phase diagrams at t=T/3 and t=2T/3

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the near-exact match between the two methods indicate?
choices: High-frequency expansion techniques are accurate for graphene.
The adiabatic-impulse approximation is accurate in the low-frequency regime.
Phase band crossings only occur at high drive frequencies.
The topology of the system is independent of drive frequency.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does each color in the plots of Figure 3 represent?
choices: Different values of radiation amplitude
Different k points in the Brillouin zone
Different adiabatic regions separated by avoided level crossings.
Different time periods

multiple_choice_question.text: What conclusion can be drawn about the accuracy of the adiabatic-impulse approximation from Figure 3?
choices: It is only accurate at specific points in time.
It is inaccurate in the presence of avoided level crossings.
It is accurate for all t ≤ T.
It is only accurate for small radiation amplitudes.
The energy eigenvalues of the system.
The Landau-Zener tunneling probability.
The phase bands for the case with two avoided level crossings.
The time evolution of the wave function coefficients.
Landau-Zener probabilities and Stueckelberg phases
Wave function coefficients in the adiabatic basis
The sum of Stueckelberg phases and kinematic phases, respectively
Time periods and drive frequencies

multiple_choice_question.text: What condition needs to be satisfied for a phase band crossing to occur according to formula (50)?
choices: ηk(tf) must be equal to zero.
The cosine of φ(2)(k, tf) must be equal to ±1.
p1k and p2k must be equal to 1.
ξ2k must be equal to zero.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the dependence of formula (50) on p1k and p2k signify?
choices: The phase bands are independent of the Landau-Zener tunneling probabilities.
The probability of phase band crossings increases with increasing Landau-Zener probabilities.
The phase bands are affected by the non-adiabatic transitions at the avoided level crossings.
Only one avoided level crossing is sufficient to induce a phase band crossing.
